Award.AwardTitle: Data Complexity and Spatial Scaling: Prediction Accuracy and Implications for Emerging Landscape Paradigms

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research will contribute new knowledge regarding the merger and aggregation of diverse geographic datasets and how their data quality loss can be minimized during these processes. As datasets are merged across varying spatial scales, statistical biases, commonly known as the Modifiable Areal Unit Problem (MAUP) occur and are impacted by the composition and configuration of the datasets. The investigator will study how these biases can be overcome in order to allow datasets to be accurately scaled to different resolutions. By developing methods that use measures of compositional and configurational heterogeneity, the researcher will provide new insights regarding how to assess the potential of a dataset to be accurately scaled to coarser and finer resolutions in order to foster integration. The investigator will raise awareness of accuracy issues surrounding appropriate and correct use of ecological, social, and geographical datasets for integrated analysis, and she will offer solutions to promote better interdisciplinary integration as well as methods for exposing young scientists to these issues through learning modules.

This project will advance the spatial sciences by drawing on parallel theories in geography and landscape ecology. The research will seek to answer three core questions: (1) How do data complexity and spatial heterogeneity impact statistical biases associated with MAUP? (2) Can standards for data reduction/complexity improve prediction? (3) Do various landscape paradigms respond differently to changing heterogeneity? The investigator will use multiple methods, including innovations in surface paradigms in the field of landscape ecology, advances in remote sensing spectral unmixing, and scale-dependency of spatial pattern metrics to answer these questions. The research findings will result in identification of different forms of data reduction and complexity aggregation methods across multiple resolutions; development of a rapid assessment method for predicting downscaling accuracy; and establishment of a statistical basis for using the emerging continuous surface paradigm of landscape analyses. These outcomes have the potential to transform how scientists across environmental, social, and economic disciplines approach aggregation and scaling of various types of geospatial data.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this era of data-driven science, researchers are able to easily gather many diverse datasets collected at widely varying spatial scales and combine them to answer pressing questions related to global environmental change. However, the process of integration often requires changing the spatial scale of one or more of these datasets, through upscaling (making the spatial scale larger) or downscaling (making the spatial scale smaller) so they are consistent and compatible with modeling software. These decisions to alter the validity of results since changing the spatial resolution through upscaling and downscaling introduces statistical biases. Numerous studies have been conducted to understand the ways in which changing the spatial scale of data can change the results of subsequent analyses, but few solutions have been developed. This project moved past simply describing problems linked to spatial scale and created solutions for translating information across scales in land cover datasets.

This project includes both theoretical advances and applications. Contributions to our basic scientific understanding of scale include (1) identifying how the composition, or amount, of different types of land cover and the configuration, or arrangement, of those different land covers affect the accuracy with which data can be upscaled and downscaled; (2) a practical assessment of scaling parameters and how these parameters change with composition and configuration; (3) a foundation for understanding how emerging gradient datasets can help in overcoming the biases that surround upscaling and downscaling datasets; and (4) a practical understanding of the usefulness of the set of surface metrics being applied to assess composition and configuration in gradient datasets.

The applied component of this project examined forest fragmentation in United States and urban change in Mexico. To support the foundation for understanding how emerging gradient datasets can be leveraged to reduce the uncertainties when aggregating categorical data, we introduced an approach for extracting landscape pattern information from gradient surfaces using a thresholding approach to discretize gradient surfaces into multiple discrete maps according to forest cover density. This work showed that not only is it possible to use traditional software tools on thresholded gradients, but that it is possible to extract far more information from these gradient datasets than is possible with categorical datasets. We also analyzed the performance and applicability of surface metrics across a range of ecoregions and scales to facilitate their adoption in landscape ecology. In the urban realm, we showed that predictable scaling relationships of land cover configuration are present across complex systems such as hierarchies of cities within a country.

Together, the theoretical advances and applications showed that (1) in categorical land cover datasets, configuration is a stronger driver of downscaling accuracy compared to composition; (2) gradient datasets do help overcome some of the biases that are introduced when categorical datasets are upscaled or downscaled. However, many of the metrics being employed to quantify patterns in these gradient datasets do not have an intuitive interpretation for practical applications, which hinders their usefulness; (3) power laws are the only form of scaling relationship robust across the entire range of composition and configuration, which suggests a potential for universal scaling laws for landscapes.  

The research results have been shared with national and international audiences through conference presentations in the fields of geography, landscape ecology, and spatial accuracy. The models and approaches developed for testing and quantifying the impacts of downscaling have been made available through code and publications and can be applied to many fields beyond geography. The project provided unique training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students in geography, geospatial technologies, statistics, and career development. In addition to presentations at conferences, workshops and seminars, the research has resulted in one dissertation, nine published journal articles, one published book chapter, one published conference proceeding, and two manuscripts submitted for publication.

Outreach to the community included development of age-appropriate STEM learning activities for elementary (K-5) and high school students (8-12) to teach them about measurement scale, aerial photography, and satellite imagery. For the elementary school students, we created puzzles of the aerial view of their hometown at different spatial scales to cultivate spatial awareness and map reading skills. The students were able to see how scale impacted the amount of detail in the maps. These activities were introduced to students during STEM fairs at schools serving primarily under-represented minorities and underserved groups. For the high school students, we paired the puzzle activity with a digital, geospatial mapping exercise to provide a hands-on learning experience to highlight the implications of working with different scales of geospatial imagery during National Lab Day, an annual event that connects high school students to science laboratories across the nation.
